content:
I am a black and trans entry level data science analyst, I was previously employed at a data science as a service company in Baltimore, MD. I have worked with clients that range from the marketing and advertising sector, biopharmecutical sector, laywers and government, as well as public spatial data for geocoding and geospatial analysis. While working with these clients I have been able to sharpen my skills and learn different languages such as R and SQL.
I am able to connect to and access multiple databases through BigQuery SQL databases, in-house client databases, as well as Cloudera Benchmark databases through R. I am able to curate, create, and manage new data from web-scraping and create functional live databases that are updated either in real-time or by user. My very first project was to create a time sheet for the company; I created a version that was initially used for the first couple of months, until my employer decided to hire out timesheet services.
Hopefully my scripts will adequately showcase my skills within the workplace. Also keep in mind my resume has to showcase my legal name; am currently going through the process of getting my name changed. Please use the contact information and credentials on this website to contact me directly.
When I’m not trying to learn new ways to make life easier with data analysis through R, I’m usually volunteering for local nonprofits, attending some awesome queer party or a being couch potato.
summary: I am a black and trans entry level data science analyst, I was previously employed at a data science as a service company in Baltimore, MD. I have worked with clients that range from the marketing and advertising sector, biopharmecutical sector, laywers and government, as well as public spatial data for geocoding and geospatial analysis.
title: Saki Hiyashi

content:
吳恩達 is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed neque elit, tristique placerat feugiat ac, facilisis vitae arcu. Proin eget egestas augue. Praesent ut sem nec arcu pellentesque aliquet. Duis dapibus diam vel metus tempus vulputate.
summary: 吳恩達 is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.
title: 吳恩達

content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

title: Example Page 2

content:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.   Slides can be added in a few ways:
 Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.  Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: An example talk using Academic's Markdown slides feature.
title: Example Talk

content:
Welcome Downloading files from Google Hire me because look at how easy I made it for you to search and extract through all those files on that cluttered shared company GDrive lol.
# libraries needed library(readr) library(googledrive) library(dplyr) library(purrr) library(stringr) options(httr_oob_default = TRUE) # Logs in to Google Drive with user credentials drive_auth() # Saves the company team drive for easy reference company_drive <- team_drive_get("Insert Company Name Here") # saving datapath datapath <- "enter/desired/path/here" # To download file: *uncomment 2 lines below* (perform once) *comment 2 lines below* # example <- drive_get("example_file.which_file_type", # team_drive = pfdrive) # keep this line # drive_download(example, path = str_c(datapath, "example_file.which_file_type")) # use correct function to read in data enter_fucntion_here This is if you need to grab a bunch of files from Google.
########## TO DOWNLOAD MULTIPLE FILES # if files have similar names example_list <- drive_find(pattern = "example", # char string that is common team_drive = company_drive) # keep this line datapath <- "enter/desired/path/here" ## To download files *uncomment 2 lines below* (perform once) *comment 2 lines below* # pwalk(example_list, # ~drive_download(as_id(..2), # ..2 refers to column 2 for the ID; KEEP THIS LINE # path = str_c(datapath, # "enter/local/dir/path/here", # ..1), # KEEP THIS LINE # overwrite = TRUE)) #KEEP THIS LINE # repeat process as necessary  Uploading files into Google Finally got all the crap done and need to upload it into the drive?
# libraries needed library(googledrive) library(purrr) library(tidyverse) # allows google to have API access options(httr_oob_default = TRUE) # authorizes users email and session info # run this to access google drive!! drive_auth() # select option 2 # when new tab pops open click work email, click allow, copy link # paste into console # get team drive directory pfdrive <- team_drive_get("Company Name") # keep this line # sets path for new specific folder for data datapath <-drive_get("enter_googledive_folder_here/add_folders/if_needed", team_drive = "Company Name") # keep this line # files saved on disk or in REnviron ------------------------------------------------ # get all files we want to upload in GDrive local_files <- list.files("/enter/file/path/here/", full.names = TRUE) # keep line # creates the folder folder <- drive_mkdir(name = "create_new_folder_in_google_drive", parent = datapath) # do not change map(local_files, drive_upload, path = folder, verbose = F) # do not change # repeat process as necessary Now you can be less stressed when someone asks for a file lol. Just run the script for two seconds after filling in the gaps! Let R do all the searching ~~
summary: Welcome Downloading files from Google Hire me because look at how easy I made it for you to search and extract through all those files on that cluttered shared company GDrive lol.
title: SO...R u hiring or nah?

content:
Geospatial Analysis This was a project I worked on that heavily relied on demographic data and geospatial analysis to meet the client’s needs. The dataset was curated while I was working at a previous company, one of the few datasets that curate arrest and charges case data in Baltimore City that was related to the Gun Trace Task Force - whose current trials are still ongoing for the officers that have been charged. Unsure for legal reasons if I can be able to post the code made to web scrape the Maryland State Case Search: once I get an update, I’ll add it to a post or a separate project.
The goal and purpose of this map was to see where the civilians who were arrested lived, their race, age and what they were arrested for.
This analysis was taking all the addresses scraped on the case search engine, pretty scary right! Before I get ahead of myself, I had to properly set up my REnviron. and make sure that I had all libraries needed to run the script:
library(sp) library(sf) library(tidyverse) library(ggmap) library(maps) library(tmap) library(tmaptools) library(htmlwidgets) Most of these packages make it easier for me to manipulate the data visually or it allows me to transform shapefiles so that my data falls upon the correct geographical markers ~~ like streets, highways and in this case county lines within Baltimore City and the surrounding areas.
So here I found a free to use shapefile of Baltimore City and Baltimore County because, man these poo poo police officers were definitely making quota! FYI, when we did the initial webscrape these guys were arresting people all over MD! Sickening!
# setting up data --------------------------------------------------------- # # load the data county_sections <- readOGR("data/raw_data/md_counties/geo_export_mdc.shp") # view attributes ---------- COUNTIES class(county_sections) extent(county_sections) crs(county_sections) plot(county_sections) # lets filter down to only baltimore area zipcodes! # we can filter for other zips after # baltimore only baltimore_county <- subset(county_sections, geodesc == "Baltimore County") baltimore_city <- subset(county_sections, geodesc == "Baltimore City") city_county <- subset(county_sections, geodesc == "Baltimore County" | geodesc == "Baltimore City") I had an address data set, but unfortunately the FULL address was in one column! Had to go ahead and just break that down. As you can see below, I extract the an address vector and call it bmoreadddy_unique because I only needed to see the unique set of addresses.
I then created an empty vector called geo_bmore which will hold the broken down columns and rows of the addresses that were collected.
# geocode normal addresses ------------------------------------------------ # just remember to reference unique list to find the rows that are messed up! # then look by case number from bmore_address, then join to full data set bmore_demo (which will eventually replace # mdcs_cop_demo_df() reference 'raw_code/demo_filters.R' file bmoreaddy_unique = unique(bmore_address$full_address) geo_bmore <- c() # i <- 1 # hit limit will run again at lunch # i = 6328 ~ end result while(i <= length(bmoreaddy_unique)) { geo_bmore_row <- geocode_OSM(bmoreaddy_unique[i]) if(is.null(geo_bmore_row)){ i <- i + 1 next; } geo_bmore_row <- tibble(obs_num = i, full_address = geo_bmore_row[[1]], # up and down lon = geo_bmore_row[[2]][1], # left to right lat = geo_bmore_row[[2]][2] ) # creating geo_bmore sp object geo_bmore <- bind_rows(geo_bmore, geo_bmore_row) i <- i + 1 } # Take a peek at problem address (ones that break the geocode code) bmoreaddy_unique[i] # Write down the bad ones! i <- i+1 save(geo_bmore, file = here::here("data/tidy_data", "geo_bmore_unique_addy.rda")) So…..if you’re not used to if, while or for loops…what just happened might’ve confused the heck out of you just now. It’s ok, I’m going to explain it as best as I can..
Basically what I’m telling R to do, is go through the vector and label each row a number, then geocode each row from the original data set. If the address does not end up being geodcoded, skip the row and go to the next row. BUT if the address was successfully geocoded, then add 4 new columns geo_bmore_row to the empty vector we created in the beginning of the code chunk geo_bmore. Thus created a new dataset of full addresses, connected with lat and lon and the observation number. The observation number allows us to trace it back to other datasets in case we need to easily join them later on in analysis.
We then bind, basically pasting together, the datasets together by rows thus created a clean data set of addresses and the connecting latitudes and longitudes. This process normally takes about 10-20 minutes, so don’t fret. I used the OSM search engine instead of Google’s because there were to many complications on the system I was running at the time of employment. OSM gave less stress ~
Next Chunk!
Remember earlier when I explained, or tried my best, that while loop and that it may skip some rows? Here is where I address the missing addresses. I needed to antijoin the final geocoded addreses, geo_bmore, with the original addresses scraped from the Maryland Case Search, bmore_address. Below are 3 examples of antijoining the two datasets using dplyr and two forms of baseR.
# quality control for missed addresses ------------------------------------ # not creating new variables, so im just going to do it like this # three different ways to anti_join # 1 no_geo_unique <- unique(bmore_address$full_address[!bmore_address$full_address%in%geo_bmore$full_address]) # 2 no_geo_case <- bmore_address[is.na(match(bmore_address$full_address, geo_bmore$full_address)), ] # 3 anti_join(bmore_address, geo_bmore, by = "full_address") Now that we have a dataset of all of the missing addresses that did not get geocoded, we are going to filter through the dataset and allow R to separate and clean the problematic rows that we could not address before!
# quality control workup -------------------------------------------------- no_geo = no_geo_case # taking away so I can get unique values no_geo = no_geo %>% select(-case_num) # takes rowname col into actual rownames no_geo = column_to_rownames(no_geo) # only gives unique addresses and keeps rownames no_geo = unique(no_geo) # add rowname col back after only getting unique addys # rownames basically = obs_num # use this to join again # no_geo = rownames_to_column(no_geo) # separating the address string problem_rows = as_tibble(str_split_fixed(no_geo$full_address, # telling R to separate by commas ", ", # there should be at least 5 separations n = 5)) # we only needed these columns which were rowname, full_address problem_rows = paste0(str_c(problem_rows$V1, ", ", problem_rows$V3, ", ", problem_rows$V5 )) # converts from vector to df or tibble problem_rows = enframe(problem_rows) # renaming for future cleaning colnames(problem_rows)[1] <- "rowname" colnames(problem_rows)[2] <- "full_address" # adds correct obs_num to tbl_df/tbl/data.frame problem_rows = problem_rows %>% mutate(rowname = rownames(no_geo)) # sets appropriate "i" for while loop below. problem_rows = column_to_rownames(problem_rows) # creating var new_geo <- c() i = 1 while(i <= length(problem_rows$full_address)) { no_geo_row <- geocode_OSM(problem_rows$full_address[i]) if(is.null(no_geo_row)){ i <- i + 1 next; } new_geo_row <- tibble(obs_num = i, full_address = no_geo_row[[1]], # up and down lon = no_geo_row[[2]][1], # left to right lat = no_geo_row[[2]][2] ) # creating geo_bmore sp object new_geo <- bind_rows(new_geo, new_geo_row) i <- i + 1 } problem_rows$full_address[i] i <- i+1 save(new_geo, file = here::here("data/tidy_data", "new_geo.rda")) The original while loop was used for the list of problematic addresses and then saved to the local disk for safe keeping. I know, I know! Why did you not just turn the loop into a function? Well I didn’t know that at this point and time in my career! But I definitely do it more later on in work!
Here is some cleaning, tidying and data maintenance I had to do before using them to map anything:
HINTS: - bmore_demo was a curated tidied dataset from all the case data that held age, race, name, address, court type, case type and other demographic data that was scraped and accumulated legally for THE FREE online using the Maryland Case Search Engine.
# collecting all data together -------------------------------------------- # these both have correct coords and addresses # lets unite them together head(new_geo) head(geo_bmore) # lets rename new_geo coded addresses so there isn't a mix up colnames(new_geo)[2] <- "geocoded_addresses" # but first we need to make sure that addresses in new_geo will match addresses # bmore_demo YIKES YIKES YIKES! # renaming col for binding purposes colnames(problem_rows)[2] <- "geocoded_address" # problem_rows = no_geo, basically matching = cbind(problem_rows, no_geo) # join new_geo and matching by geocoded_addresses new_geo = left_join(new_geo, matching, by = "geocoded_address") # take away incorrect current $obs_num and $geocoded_address new_geo = new_geo %>% select(-obs_num) new_geo = new_geo %>% select(-geocoded_address) # lets rearrange col order for perfect alignment new_geo = new_geo[, c(3,4,1,2)] # change rowname to finally correct obs_num colnames(new_geo)[1] <- "obs_num" # let's rbind with geo_bmore and finally start mapping!!!!!!!!!! geo_bmore = rbind(geo_bmore, new_geo) geo_bmore = geo_bmore %>% arrange(as.double(obs_num)) # RUN TO MATCH geo_bmore DATASET - comment out after running # bmore_demo$full_address = paste0(str_c(bmore_demo$full_address, ", USA")) # DO NOT RUN UNTIL ALL GEOCODES HAVE BEEN ACCOUNTED FOR # lets use tmap package to see if we can get some coords bmore_demo = left_join(geo_bmore, bmore_demo, by = "full_address") # nrow(bmore_demo) # 6721 # FILTER FOR ONLY DISTRICT COURT CASES bmore_demo <- bmore_demo %>% filter(case_type_2 != "Other") # nrow(bmore_demo) # 6078 ~ geocoded # 7687 ~ filtered # 7748 ~ original # cases # Filter out Circuit Court cases bmore_demo <- bmore_demo[str_detect(bmore_demo$court, "District"),] # nrow(bmore_demo) - 80.46% retained # geo_coded ~ 3645 # filtered ~ 4530 bmore_demo_geo = bmore_demo # save this demo as bmore_demo_geo.rda # please keep original data set!!!! save(bmore_demo_geo, file = here::here("data/tidy_data", "bmore_demo_geo.rda")) Creating a dataset of markers. Nothing special
HINTS: - mdcs_demo_dfc was a semi tidy dataset that inlcuded all cases that were related to any of the officers that were apart of the Gun Trace Task Force in both the Circuit and District Court circuits.
# creating markers -------------------------------------------------------- # UPDATE AND RERUN EVERY TIME NEW GEO_BMORE SP DATA IS ADDED # keeps only data that was geocoded bmore_plot1 <- left_join(geo_bmore, bmore_address, by = "full_address") # keeps all rows and data # bmore_plot2 <- left_join(bmore_address, # geo_bmore, # by = "full_address") # save under data set that has filtered out district court cases bmoredemo_markers1 <- left_join(bmore_plot1, mdcs_demo_dfc, by = "case_num") # keeps all rows and data # bmoredemo_markers2 <- left_join(bmore_plot2, # mdcs_demo_dfc, # by = "case_num") # have to do some sligt cleaning ~ run when data is new # bmoredemo_markers1 = bmoredemo_markers1 %>% select(-full_address.y) # colnames(bmoredemo_markers1)[colnames(bmoredemo_markers1) == "full_address.x"] <- "full_address" # this adds the charges data to the dataset bmoredemo_markers1 <- left_join(mdcs_charges_df, bmoredemo_markers1, by = "case_num") # filtering out what I need only for demographic data bmoredemo_markers1 = bmoredemo_markers1 %>% dplyr::select(case_num, full_address, lat, lon, race_black, race_cat, age_yrs, sex_id, case_type, case_type_2, ) %>% group_by(case_num) %>% ungroup() # there are two incomplete addresses that are throwing the map off. # bmoredemo_markers1 = bmoredemo_markers1 %>% filter(!case_num == "XXXXXXXX"|!case_num == "XXXXXXXXXXXXX") # bmoredemo_markers1 = bmoredemo_markers1[bmoredemo_markers1$case_num != "XXXXXXXXXX", ] # bmoredemo_markers1 = bmoredemo_markers1[bmoredemo_markers1$case_num != "XXXXXXXXXX", ] # saves into local environment save(bmoredemo_markers1, file = here::here("data/tidy_data", "bmore_markers.rda")) OKAY~~
So if you made it this far to see the maps….well good luck because I can only show you the code because of our American Justice System, and the fact that I respect my old employer lol…
This is where I allow my artist creativity run wild…within the confines of R and Leaflet!
# making the base map vars ------------------------------------------------ # sex ~ M/F sex_icons <- colorFactor(c("#0d2666", "#53a097", "#682140"), domain = unique(bmoredemo_markers1$sex_id)) # mult races racecat_icons <- colorFactor(c("#78840b", "#036852", "#a53208"), domain = unique(bmoredemo_markers1$race_cat)) # black/nonblack raceblack_icons <- colorFactor(c("#ffa500", "#b7b2ac"), domain = unique(bmoredemo_markers1$race_black)) # age pal <- colorNumeric(palette = diverge_hcl(5, "Berlin"), domain = bmoredemo_markers1$age_yrs) Now I know you guys are like, why only two genders… well our legal justice system doesn’t see otherwise unfortunately so there’s a whole subset of data unaccounted for to go along with broken window policing… oh yea..if you’re guessing hate crimes or sex workers being arrested…you were on the right path. Unfortunately our client was really interested on the impact these officers had on the urban community so they were interested to see whether the officers were indeed practicing broken window policing OR was it a big misunderstanding?
I mean…our company alone scraped over 10,000 cases in a 7-10 year time frame…while the news under reported per usual. So…they were just being shit cops. The race categories were WHITE, BLACK, and OTHER.
Below is where all the work from above, and the work not seen that will be uploaded to other projects..cough cough. The map was interactive and super colorful. Like I mentioned earlier, let me see if I can post a picture here after talking to my previoud employer.
Thanks for stopping by ~
# map making -------------------------------------------------------------- # REMINDER: every time new variations are made must run empty leaflet line # or the map will just be written over and not rerun # attribution = 'Map tiles by <a href="http://stamen.com">Stamen Design</a>, <a href="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0">CC BY 3.0</a> &mdash; Map data &copy; <a href="http://www.openstreetmap.org/copyright">OpenStreetMap</a>. *Displayed cases are 80% of total data set aggregated. Cases are over a period of ~10yrs. # creates map object bmore_map = leaflet() # adding data # examples say to put addLayersControl() at end of map making bmore_map = bmore_map %>% addTiles('http://{s}.basemaps.cartocdn.com/dark_all/{z}/{x}/{y}.png', attribution = 'Map tiles by <a href="http://stamen.com">Stamen Design</a>, <a href="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0">CC BY 3.0</a> &mdash; Map data &copy; <a href="http://www.openstreetmap.org/copyright">OpenStreetMap</a>. *Displayed cases are 80% of total data set aggregated. Cases are over a period of ~10yrs. Problem Forward &copy' ) %>% fitBounds(-76.89493, 39.19533, -76.32139, 39.72115) %>% addPolygons(data = baltimore_county, group = "County", color = "#b799ff", fill = FALSE) %>% addPolygons(data = baltimore_city, group = "City", color = "#c0a5ff", fill = FALSE) %>% addCircles(data = bmoredemo_markers1, lng = ~lon, lat = ~lat, group = "Points", popup = bmoredemo_markers1$case_num, weight = 3, radius = 40, stroke = TRUE, fillOpacity = 0.8, color = "#ff0000", label = ~ c(as.character(bmoredemo_markers1$case_num), as.character(bmoredemo_markers1$charge_desc)), options = markerClusterOptions(removeOutsideVisibleBounds = TRUE)) %>% addCircles(data = bmoredemo_markers1, lng = ~lon, lat = ~lat, group = "Black/Non-Black", popup = bmoredemo_markers1$race_black, weight = 3, radius = 40, stroke = TRUE, fillOpacity = 0.8, color = ~raceblack_icons(race_black), label = ~as.character(bmoredemo_markers1$race_black), options = markerClusterOptions(removeOutsideVisibleBounds = TRUE)) %>% addLegend("bottomright", colors = c("#ffa500", "#b7b2ac"), labels = c("Black", "Non-Black"), title = "Cases by Race", group = "Black/Non-Black") %>% addCircles(data = bmoredemo_markers1, lng = ~lon, lat = ~lat, group = "Black/White/Other", popup = bmoredemo_markers1$race_cat, weight = 3, radius = 40, stroke = TRUE, fillOpacity = 0.8, color = ~racecat_icons(race_cat), label = ~as.character(bmoredemo_markers1$case_num), options = markerClusterOptions(removeOutsideVisibleBounds = TRUE)) %>% addLegend("bottomright", colors = c("#78840b", "#036852", "#a53208"), labels = c("Black", "Other/Unknown", "White"), title = "Cases by Race Mult", group = "Black/White/Other", labFormat = labelFormat(group = "Black/White/Other")) %>% addCircles(data = bmoredemo_markers1, lng = ~lon, lat = ~lat, group = "Female/Male", popup = bmoredemo_markers1$sex_id, weight = 3, radius = 40, stroke = TRUE, fillOpacity = 0.8, color = ~sex_icons(sex_id), label = ~as.character(bmoredemo_markers1$sex_id), options = markerClusterOptions(removeOutsideVisibleBounds = TRUE)) %>% addLegend("bottomleft", colors = c( "#53a097", "#0d2666", "#682140"), labels = c("Male", "Female", "Other/Unknown"), title = "Cases by Sex", group = "Female/Male", labFormat = labelFormat()) %>% addCircles(data = bmoredemo_markers1, lng = ~lon, lat = ~lat, group = "Age", weight = 2, radius = 25, stroke = TRUE, fillOpacity = 0.5, color = ~pal(age_yrs), label = ~as.character(bmoredemo_markers1$age_yrs), options = markerClusterOptions(removeOutsideVisibleBounds = TRUE)) %>% addLegend("bottomleft", pal = pal, values = bmoredemo_markers1$age_yrs, title = "Age", group = "Age") %>% addLayersControl(overlayGroups = c("City", "County"), baseGroups = c("Points", "Black/Non-Black", "Black/White/Other", "Female/Male", "Age"), options = layersControlOptions(collapsed = TRUE, autoZIndex = TRUE)) %>% hideGroup(c("Points", "Black/Non-Black", "Black/White/Other", "Female/Male", "Age")) # data added on the map # saves map htmlwidgets::saveWidget(bmore_map, file = here::here("products/bmore_map.html"), selfcontained = FALSE) webshot("products/bmore_map.html", file = here::here("products/bmore_map.png", cliprect = "viewport")) mapshot(bmore_map, url = paste0(getwd(), "/bmore_map.html")) # actual function # function (map, urlTemplate = "//{s}.tile.openstreetmap.org/{z}/{x}/{y}.png", # attribution = NULL, layerId = NULL, group = NULL, options = tileOptions()) # { # options$attribution = attribution # if (missing(urlTemplate) && is.null(options$attribution)) # options$attribution = paste("&copy; <a href=\"http://openstreetmap.org\">OpenStreetMap</a>", # "contributors, <a href=\"http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0/\">CC-BY-SA</a>") # invokeMethod(map, getMapData(map), "addTiles", urlTemplate, # layerId, group, options) # } # edited function # addTiles = function (map, urlTemplate = "**http:**//{s}.tile.openstreetmap.org/{z}/{x}/{y}.png", # attribution = NULL, layerId = NULL, group = NULL, options = tileOptions()) # { # options$attribution = attribution # if (missing(urlTemplate) && is.null(options$attribution)) # options$attribution = paste("© <a href=\"http://openstreetmap.org\">OpenStreetMap", # "contributors, <a href=\"http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0/\">CC-BY-SA") # invokeMethod(map, getMapData(map), "addTiles", urlTemplate, # layerId, group, options) # }
summary: Geospatial Analysis This was a project I worked on that heavily relied on demographic data and geospatial analysis to meet the client’s needs. The dataset was curated while I was working at a previous company, one of the few datasets that curate arrest and charges case data in Baltimore City that was related to the Gun Trace Task Force - whose current trials are still ongoing for the officers that have been charged.
title: Geospatial Analysis on Civilians Arrested by the Gun Trace Task Force

content:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic  Academic | Documentation
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click  PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")   Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}  Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
 A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}} - Only the speaker can read these notes - Press `S` key to view {{% /speaker_note %}}  Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}}   Custom CSS Example Let’s make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }   Questions?  Ask
 Documentation
